content: The "Combating Terrorism Financing Act of 2005" increases penalties for terrorism financing under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act. Penalties are raised to $50,000 and twenty years for violations related to money laundering activities. Amendments to RICO and Section 1956(c)(7) of title 18, United States Code are made to include new offenses such as illegal money transmitters, unlawful employment of aliens, financing of terrorism, and misuse of a social security number. Investigations of violations can be conducted by various components of the Department of Justice, Department of the Treasury, Department of Homeland Security, and the United States Postal Service, as directed by the respective authorities. Additionally, violations involving offenses described in paragraph (c)(7)(E) may be investigated by the Department of Justice and the National Enforcement Investigations Center of the Environmental Protection Agency. The Secretary of Homeland Security, the Secretary of the Treasury, and the Postal Service have authority to investigate offenses under an agreement with the Attorney General. SEC. 4. ASSETS OF PERSONS COMMITTING TERRORIST ACTS AGAINST FOREIGN COUNTRIES OR INTERNATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS. Section 981(a)(1)(G) of title 18, United States Code is amended to include forfeiture of property belonging to individuals, entities, or organizations involved in planning or carrying out acts of international terrorism against international organizations or foreign governments. The amendment to Section 981(a)(1)(G) of title 18, United States Code allows for forfeiture of property related to acts of international terrorism against international organizations or foreign governments, with the condition that the planning or perpetration occurred within the jurisdiction of the United States. SEC. 5. MONEY LAUNDERING THROUGH HAWALAS. Amends Section 1956 of title 18, United States Code to include definitions of transactions involving proceeds of unlawful activity. SEC. 6. TECHNICAL AND CONFORMING AMENDMENTS RELATING TO THE USA PATRIOT ACT. Section 322 of Public Law 107-56 is amended to change "title 18" to "title 28". Section 5332(a)(1) of title 31, United States Code, is amended to include "mail" in addition to "article of luggage". Sections 1956(b)(3) and (4) of title 18, United States Code, are amended to remove references to paragraph (2). Section 981(k) of title 18, United States Code, is amended to include "financial institution" alongside "foreign bank". Chapter 46 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to add a new section titled "Anti-terrorist forfeiture protection". ``Sec. 987. Anti-terrorist forfeiture protection allows property owners to contest confiscation by filing a claim under Federal Rules of Civil Procedure. Evidence admissibility may be flexible to ensure reliability. The curr_chunk discusses clarifications regarding the exclusion of certain provisions of Federal law from the definition of the term 'civil forfeiture statute' to protect property owners' rights to contest asset confiscation of suspected international terrorists. It also includes a savings clause stating that this section does not limit other available remedies. The curr_chunk adds a savings clause to protect property owners' rights under section 983 or other laws, without limiting other available remedies. The curr_chunk includes amendments to various sections of the United States Code related to anti-terrorist forfeiture protection and technical corrections to the financing of terrorism statute. SEC. 8 amends Section 5318(n)(4)(A) of title 31, US Code. SEC. 9 makes amendments to Section 6604 of the Intelligence Reform and Terrorism Prevention Act of 2004. SEC. 10 designates an additional money laundering predicate. SEC. 10 designates an additional money laundering predicate by amending Section 1956(c)(7)(D) of title 18, US Code to include receiving military-type training from a foreign terrorist organization.
